abstract: When Japanese cars began arriving in the United States in earnest in the 1970s, they were widely seen as disposable, writes Richard S. Chang. Reliable, maybe. Future classics? Not likely. But in the past decade, those bargain-price models from the '70s and '80s have been revisited by a generation of enthusiasts who grew up riding in the back seats. Read the article »
lead_paragraph: When Japanese cars began arriving in the United States in earnest in the 1970s, they were widely seen as disposable, writes Richard S. Chang. Reliable, maybe. Future classics? Not likely. But in the past decade, those bargain-price models from the '70s and '80s have been revisited by a generation of enthusiasts who grew up riding in the back seats. Read the article »

headline.main: Japanese Cars From the 1970s Become Classics in America
